q: What are the symptoms of epidermolysis bullosa?
i: Epidermolysis bullosa symptoms include skin that blisters easily, blisters on the hands and soles of the feet, thickened skin, and thickening of the skin and nails.
a: Common symptoms of epidermolysis bullosa include easily blistering skin, blisters on the hands and soles of the feet, thickened skin, and thickening of the skin and nails.

q: What are the types of epidermolysis bullosa?
i: Epidermolysis bullosa has three main types: epidermolysis bullosa simplex (EBS), dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa (DEB), and junctional epidermolysis bullosa (JEB).
a: The three main types of epidermolysis bullosa are epidermolysis bullosa simplex (EBS), dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa (DEB), and junctional epidermolysis bullosa (JEB).

q: How is epidermolysis bullosa diagnosed?
a: Epidermolysis bullosa is usually diagnosed in babies and young children based on their symptoms. Tests, such as a skin biopsy, may be done to determine the type of EB.

q: What causes epidermolysis bullosa?
a: Epidermolysis bullosa is caused by a faulty gene mutation that makes the skin more fragile. It can be inherited from a parent or occur spontaneously.

q: How is epidermolysis bullosa treated?
a: There is currently no cure for epidermolysis bullosa. The treatment focuses on managing symptoms and preventing complications. This may include popping blisters, applying protective dressings, and using medications to treat infection and reduce pain.

q: What is epidermolysis bullosa acquisita?
a: Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita (EBA) is a rare acquired form of EB that causes the skin to blister easily. It is not inherited and often develops later in life.

q: Are there any charities or support groups for epidermolysis bullosa?
a: Yes, there are organizations like DEBRA and Cure EB that provide help, advice, and support for people living with or affected by epidermolysis bullosa.

q: What is the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service?
a: The National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service (NCARDRS) is a register that collects information about people with rare diseases like epidermolysis bullosa. This helps scientists in research and treatment development.

q: How can I opt out of the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service?
a: You can opt out of the register at any time. For more information, you can visit the GOV.UK website.

q: What tests can be done to diagnose epidermolysis bullosa during pregnancy?
a: Prenatal tests such as amniocentesis and chorionic villus sampling can be done after the 11th week of pregnancy to test for epidermolysis bullosa if there is a risk of having a severe type of EB.

q: What are the common symptoms of epidermolysis bullosa?
a: Common symptoms in all types of EB include: skin that blisters easily, blisters on the hands and soles of the feet, thickened skin that may be scarred or change color over time, thickening of the skin and nails.

q: What are the 3 main types of epidermolysis bullosa?
a: The main types of EB are epidermolysis bullosa simplex (EBS), dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa (DEB), and junctional epidermolysis bullosa (JEB).

q: How is epidermolysis bullosa diagnosed?
a: EB is usually diagnosed in babies and young children, as the symptoms can be obvious from birth. Tests, such as a skin biopsy, may be done to determine the type of EB and develop a treatment plan.

q: What causes epidermolysis bullosa?
a: EB is caused by a faulty gene mutation that makes the skin more fragile. It can be inherited from one or both parents who may or may not have EB themselves, or it can occur spontaneously.

q: How is epidermolysis bullosa treated?
a: There is currently no cure for EB, but treatment focuses on relieving symptoms and preventing complications. This can include popping blisters, applying protective dressings, avoiding triggers, and using medications for infections or pain relief. Surgery may be required in some cases.

q: What is epidermolysis bullosa acquisita?
a: Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita (EBA) is an acquired form of EB that causes the skin to blister easily. It is not inherited and usually appears later in life. EBA is an autoimmune disease.

q: Are there any charities or support groups for people with EB?
a: Yes, there are organizations such as DEBRA and Cure EB that provide help, advice, and support for people living with or affected by EB. These charities fund research and offer resources for patients and caregivers.

q: Can you opt out of the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service?
a: Yes, you can opt out of the register at any time if you or your child has EB. The register helps scientists gather information to improve prevention and treatment methods for rare diseases.

q: What are some management strategies for living with EB?
a: Managing EB involves popping blisters with a sterile needle, applying protective dressings, avoiding exacerbating factors, and using medication for pain relief or infection treatment. Surgery may also be necessary in certain cases.

q: When does epidermolysis bullosa usually appear?
a: EB is usually apparent from birth in babies and young children, although milder forms may not be diagnosed until adulthood. Symptoms vary depending on the type of EB and its severity.
